title: Committee calls for stronger safeguards and oversight on latest instalment of counter-terrorism laws
abstract: Federal Parliament's Joint Committee on Intelligence and Security has called for significant changes to the latest counter-terrorism proposals but also recommended the bill be passed. It says the Government should not be able to declare an entire county a 'no go zone' and the bill should not authorise the collection of data like fingerprints and iris scans at airports. The report also calls for the laws to be reviewed two years after the next election rather than in a decade.

title: Sending Australian medics to Ebola region a doomed mission says expert
abstract: Australia's leading infectious disease expert has backed the Abbott Government's refusal to send Australian medical personnel to help with the Ebola crisis. Professor Peter Collignon says despite the desperate situation for medical staff now trying to deal with the Ebola crisis, Australia was so far away from west Africa the logistics would be impossible. Infected Australians would also face almost certain death if forced to fly 30 hours back to Australia for treatment.

title: 'Big' Jim Byrnes accused of fabricating evidence to trade union royal commission to settle old score
abstract: The reputation and credit of a colourful Sydney businessman was called into question today as the trade union royal commission was recalled to hear more about alleged bribes paid to a CFMEU official. The businessman known as 'Big' Jim Byrnes fronted the royal commission again to face cross-examination by lawyers representing the two alleged parties to the bribe: union organiser Darren Greenfield, and another distinctive Sydney businessman, George Alex. Jim Byrnes has previously told the royal commission he saw the pair exchange an envelope stuffed with $3,000 in cash. Today he denied fabricating that story in a bid to get even with Mr Alex.

title: Volatility is back on financial markets
abstract: After one of the wildest weeks in years, the Australian stock market has finished in the black, up about 1.4 per cent for the week. But there have been wild gyrations all week, across the globe. It looks set to continue, with Reserve Bank deputy governor Guy Debelle issuing an extraordinary warning of a violent correction. To make sense of all this is the ABC's business editor Ian Verrender.

title: Kelly quits Liberals labelling party in NSW 'a joke'
abstract: She was once a hero to her prime minister but now former western Sydney federal MP Jackie Kelly has quit the Liberal Party labelling it a 'joke' in NSW. Ms Kelly says it's riven by factionalism and that she's tired of waiting for promises to clean it up. Tony Abbott has responded by saying he hopes anyone disgruntled will push for reform from within the party rather than quitting first. Ms Kelly says she's now free to argue and campaign against a second Sydney airport at Badgery's Creek, a government policy she cannot support.

title: HBO's streaming move shakes up pay TV industry
abstract: They call it cable cutting and it's turning the pay television industry on its head. As audiences continue to shift from watching programs on television to online, one of the leading US pay TV companies has announced its launching a direct streaming service for US audiences. The move by HBO is a direct threat to existing online streaming companies, such as Netflix, and could hurt local cable providers such as Foxtel.

title: New book examines Nazi Party membership
abstract: Plenty of factors lie behind the chaos in Iraq that helped lead to the rise of the so-called Islamic State, but most experts believe that the US decision to get rid of everyone in the administration who'd belonged to Saddam Hussein's Ba'ath Party was one of them. De-Ba'athification was a deliberate echo of de-Nazification - the process of weeding out Hitler's top leadership after World War Two. Author of a new book, Post-war Lies, Malte Herwig, talks with PM about Nazi Party history.

title: The man who changed Australia
abstract: Gough Whitlam was one of the few Australian leaders to have so comprehensively captured the national imagination. Considered a silvertail, with no trade union background, he was not the typical Labor member of the times, but he became the man the party needed to forge a broad coalition across all parts of society. His legacy includes Aboriginal land rights, the recognition of China and the establishment of the foundations of Medicare, but his ambition to implement his program for government outlined in that speech ended up trumping other critical considerations.
subject: gough whitlam;  politics;  margaret whitlam;  labor;  government;  australia; the dismissal; Human Interest -- People

title: Emotional and good humoured tributes for Whitlam in Parliament
abstract: The Prime Minister and Opposition Leader have led bipartisan tributes to Australia's 21st prime minister during a special sitting of Parliament. All other business was suspended to celebrate Gough Whitlam's enduring legacy of public service, his sizeable ego, and his vision for Australia.

abstract: John Mant was the prime minister's principal private secretary when Gough Whitlam was prime minister, for the five months leading up to Whitlam's dismissal in 1975. title: Son of Balibo Five cameraman disappointed war crimes investigation dropped
abstract: The son of one of the five Australian newsmen killed in the town of Balibo in East Timor in 1975 says he's greatly disappointed the AFP has dropped a war crimes investigation into the deaths. A 2007 coronial inquest found the men had been deliberately killed by Indonesian forces and recommended those responsible be prosecuted. But the AFP says its five-year investigation faced challenges such as establishing jurisdiction and says there's not enough evidence to prove an offence. John Milkins, the son of the Channel Seven cameraman Garry Cunningham, says he wants to know more about why the investigation has been dropped.

title: Gough Whitlam remembered fondly in China
abstract: As opposition leader in 1971, Gough Whitlam made a groundbreaking visit to Beijing for which he was criticised at home. It was the height of the Cold War, and engaging the Communist giant was controversial, but his trip was soon seen as a diplomatic masterstroke when eight months later US president Richard Nixon shocked the world by making his own visit there.

abstract: The Federal Government's revealed it intends to scale back the renewable energy target to what it calls 'a real 20 per cent' target, just before sitting down with Labor in a bid to get a new bipartisan agreement. The wind power industry says that will 'decimate' the clean energy sector. Even before the announcement Labor dismissed it as a fraud and a fake.

title: Royal Commission hears child broke own arm to avoid further abuse
abstract: The Royal Commission has revealed that the couple who ran the Bethcar Children's home, Bert and Edith Gordon, were honoured by the state government for their outstanding work in caring for abandoned children in 1980. But in the same year, community services were first alerted to problems of sexual abuse at the home in Brewarrina. For the residents, the experiences at the government-funded home set them up for a life of disadvantage: drug and alcohol addiction, mental and physical illness, run-ins with the law, domestic violence and a prevailing belief that they have failed their own children who are now in foster care. The inquiry is looking not only at the stories of abuse at the home between the 1970s and 80s, but asking serious questions about the conduct of the lawyers acting for the state during the former residents' six year legal battle for compensation.

title: 'Immaterial' if Coalition weapons go to Islamic militants: CDF
abstract: The Chief of the Defence Force says it's immaterial if weapons dropped by the US-led coalition in Iraq and Syria end up in the hands of Islamic militants rather than Kurdish fighters. Air Chief Marshall Mark Binskin says the majority are reaching their intended target, and the rebels in cities like Kobane must continue to receive the weapons and aid if they are to defeat the militants.

title: Giant of American newspapers, Watergate editor dies

He edited the Washington Post for almost 30 years, most notably when it was leading the coverage of the Watergate scandal, turning the paper from a serious publication to one of national importance.

title: Government insists Australia is ready to fight Ebola in the region

The virus, which has claimed thousands of lives in west Africa, was discussed repeatedly in estimates hearings at Parliament House. One outspoken Senator even raised the prospect of Ebola infected terrorists.

title: Greste and colleagues told appeal won't be heard for over two months
abstract: This weekend the Australian journalist Peter Greste and his two al Jazeera Television colleagues will mark 300 days in a Cairo jail. They were sentenced to seven years and 10 years respectively after what was internationallly condemned as a travesty of justice in an Egyptian court. Now they've been told that their appeal against the legality of that trial won't even be heard until they've done another two-and-a-half months in Tora prison. PM speaks to Peter Greste's parents are Brisbane based Lois and Juris Greste.

title: Vietnam releases prominent blogger from prison
abstract: Vietnam's government has released one of its most prominent political prisoners after six years in jail. The blogger Nguyen Van Hai, better known as Dieu Cay, was jailed for writing critically about Vietnam's relationship with China and criticising China's actions in disputed waters. He's now to live in exile in the United States. Activists say his release is cause for optimism that the Communist country is gradually liberalising, but they've warned more than two-dozen journalists remain behind bars there.

title: Blackwater judgment could have worldwide implications
abstract: A jury in Washington has convicted one man of first degree murder and three others of manslaughter over a massacre that happened in Baghdad seven years ago. title: Crown solicitors accused of 'rank hypocrisy' over Bethcar abuse litigation
abstract: The royal commission has revealed an unflattering picture of the strategy and tactics adopted by the state and its legal advisers when 15 former residents of the Bethcar children's home tried to bring a case against the state government over the abuse they suffered at the home. title: Australia: what happened after the 'war to end all wars'
abstract: Writer Tom Keneally's new book, Australians: Flappers to Vietnam, is a vast historical sweep. But it begins with the end of the war to end all wars and the 1920s. PM began by asking Mr Keneally about the soldier-settlers and the pockets of land they were given to build their lives on.

title: Rallies held for Ms Dhu's death in custody
abstract: Rallies have been held across the country today in memory of Aboriginal woman Ms Dhu, who died in police custody in August. The 22-year-old was locked up in a West Australian police station for unpaid fines and while in custody complained of rib pain from a previous injury. She was taken to hospital on three occasions, but died on her third visit. Ms Dhu's cause of death isn't yet known and today her family took their grief, and anger, to the streets. Emotions were high, as news of another Aboriginal death in custody overnight came to light.

title: Australia's rejection of costly new cure a death sentence for hep C sufferers
abstract: Liver experts have warned Australia's recent refusal to subsidise a breakthrough cure for the country's quarter of a million hepatitis C sufferers could effectively deliver a death sentence to up to 50,000 Australians in the next few years. Australian gastroenterologist Dr Miriam Levy told a conference on the Gold Coast the situation was so desperate for many hepatitis C sufferers Australia needed to set up its own version of a Dallas Buyers Club. Australia is the only developed country in the world that has not agreed to subsidise the new $70,000 treatment for the most seriously ill patients, citing high costs as the barrier.
subject: hepatitis c;  cures; Arts and Entertainment -- Film (Movies)
rights: Copyright 2014 Australian Broadcasting Corporation. Other rights may be held as detailed in text. http://www.abc.net.au/conditions.htm#UseOfContent

title: Hollywood targets Australian web users directly in latest copyright campaign
abstract: Australian internet users are being directly targeted in the latest attempt by Hollywood to crackdown on illegal movie downloading. The makers of the hit Dallas Buyers Club are trying to force a handful of Australian internet companies to hand over details of customers who illegally download the film. The legal action is the latest salvo in a longstanding campaign by the film industry to reduce piracy, which filmmakers say is still rampant. But several of the internet companies are fighting the court action, citing privacy concerns.
subject: copyright;  infringement;  digital;  piracy;  online;  downloads;  torrent;  communications;  web; internet; Information and Communication -- Copyright
rights: Copyright 2014 Australian Broadcasting Corporation. Other rights may be held as detailed in text. http://www.abc.net.au/conditions.htm#UseOfContent

title: New York doctor sick with Ebola
abstract: New York has recorded its first diagnosed case of Ebola, with a 33-year-old doctor testing positive to the deadly virus. The Big Apple's health officials say they've learnt from Dallas' mistakes. Dr Craig Spencer recently returned from treating Ebola patients in Guinea for Medecins Sans Frontieres.

title: 'It's a good start': EU leaders strike deal on carbon emissions
abstract: In talks stretching late in to the night, European Union leaders have struck a deal to cut greenhouse gas emissions by at least 40 per cent by 2030. Climate advocates say the target needs to be higher but it's a good opening gambit as countries reveal their emissions pledges ahead of critical climate talks in Paris next year.

title: Head of department says 'sorry' to abuse victims from Bethcar children's home
abstract: The head of the New South Wales Department of Family and Community Services, Michael Coutts-Trotter, has apologised to the former Bethcar residents for the abuse they suffered, and for the re-traumatising and shameful demands the state's lawyers put to victims when they tried to bring a civil claim. The child abuse royal commission has heard the protracted litigation cost taxpayers more than $3.5 million and it could have been avoided if the state's lawyers had dealt with the case more sensitively and efficiently.

title: Commonwealth, WA agree to give state officials more say on sharks
abstract: The West Australian Premier Colin Barnett says his Government and the Commonwealth have agreed to give officials more power to destroy sharks where they pose an imminent threat to people. The details around what those powers will be, and precisely when they can be exercised, are still being worked through. But the Greens are worried the agreement gives de facto approval to drum lines.

title: 30th anniversary of first contact with last group of Indigenous people to meet white Australia
abstract: Today marks the 30th anniversary of the last remaining group of Indigenous Australians to make contact with 'white Australia'. The group of Indigenous Australians became known as the 'Pintupi Nine' and they were discovered, living a traditional hunter gatherer life, almost 200 years after European settlers first landed on their shores. Their first contact with white Australia was a media sensation. Three decades after they first laid eyes on white Australians, the Pintupi Nine have been telling their version of that day at Lake Mackay in Western Australia's Gibson desert.

title: Fears higher education changes could damage Indigenous student enrolments
abstract: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islanders are still severely under-represented in tertiary education. Some universities are working to change that, like the University of NSW. But there are fears the Federal Government's proposed changes to higher education could wind back progress.

title: Federal Government denies caving into banks on CBA financial planning scandal
abstract: The Federal Government has denied it's caved into the big banks by rejecting calls for a royal commission into a financial planning scandal at the Commonwealth Bank. Instead the Government will set up a public register of financial planners which will name and shame rogue operators. But the former Commonwealth Bank employee who blew the whistle on the scandal says he is extremely disappointed there are no plans for a royal commission.

title: Secrets and betrayal in Peter Carey's Amnesia
abstract: Peter Carey's latest novel, Amnesia, delves into the nature of computer hacking and what it means for Australia and the world. The central character Gaby is the hacker, and the narrator is a shambling journalist from the '70s who's been hired to write her story. PM's Mark Colvin talks to author Peter Carey.

title: Qantas share holders approve $2.5 million bonus for Alan Joyce
abstract: Qantas boss Alan Joyce has been handed a massive incentive to turn his struggling company's fortunes around. Shareholders have agreed to pay the chief executive a $2.5 million bonus if he can transform Qantas into one of the world's most valuable airlines. Mr Joyce has told today's annual general meeting in Melbourne that the business has already returned to profit.

title: Swiss yodelling gets serious
abstract: The Swiss government wants the United Nations to have the highly rarefied art of Swiss yodelling added to the World Heritage List. It may sit oddly alongside the manmade wonders of the Taj Mahal or Stonehenge. But in 2003 UNESCO agreed to a new category of so called intangible heritage - listings which have already included an eccentric range of practices from the Argentinean tango to falconry.

title: Jokowi reveals his new 'working cabinet'
abstract: Indonesia's new president has revealed his senior ministerial line-up. Said to feature a mix of old hands and technocrats, it includes the country's first female foreign minister. It's the team that the new president will have to rely on for help to meet his promises to curb corruption, cut fuel subsidies, reduce bureaucracy and build infrastructure.

title: Govt outlines plan for second asylum seeker to be returned to Afghanistan
abstract: Refugee groups are pleading with the Federal Government to halt the planned deportation of an Afghan man whose claim for asylum failed and who's due to be sent to Kabul tomorrow. Along with the Government's letter to the failed asylum seeker outlining plans for his deportation came a bill for his removal of more than $25,000. If he's sent back, he'll be the second afghan man to be forcibly deported by the Abbott Government.

title: Hydro Tasmania cancels King Island wind farm project
abstract: A $2 billion wind farm project for Tasmania's King Island has been cancelled, after the state-owned power generator said it was not economically viable. If it had gone ahead, the project would have generated 600 megawatts of electricity with 200 turbines, supplying the national energy market via an under-water high-voltage cable.

title: Labor says Barnaby Joyce broke parliamentary rules by altering hansard to correct his error
abstract: The Federal Opposition's accused the Agriculture Minister, Barnaby Joyce, of breaking parliamentary rules. Labor said it was among the most serious breaches of the rules and tried to move a censure motion against him - but the Government used its numbers to block the motion. Mr Joyce has since told Parliament the change was requested by his staff and they have been counselled.

title: Match fixing threating Australian sport
abstract: It's estimated that 25 per cent of world sport is now controlled by organised crime. Match fixing has been identified as the biggest issue facing sport in the world today - far outstripping doping. Cricket Australia is offering an amnesty for anyone coming forward with information on match fixing ahead of next year's world cup. An Irish professor who specialises in the area says Australian sporting bodies need to be doing more to try to stem the flow of corruption.

title: Heroes or pariahs, US struggles to deal with returning ebola health workers
abstract: In the United States, a nurse has hired a civil rights lawyer to challenge the strict new mandatory quaranting policy. Despite showing no symptoms, she was isolated in a tent inside a New Jersey hospital the day she arrived back from Sierra Leone. She now says she feels like a criminal. In Australia, a leading public health expert has warned against automatically quarantining or isolating health workers returning from West Africa.

title: Pork industry backs push for 'country of origin' labelling reform

But while there's general consensus among politicians, farmers and consumers that the current system is confusing, successive reviews haven't lead to change. The pork industry has welcomed the latest set of recommendations, but consumer advocates Choice say the committee didn't go far enough.

title: Trans Pacific trade deal edges closer
abstract: Federal Trade Minister, Andrew Robb, says significant progress has been made in an ambitious trade deal which spans the Pacific. Trade ministers from 11 countries and Australia are in Sydney for the latest round of trade talks on the Trans Pacific Partnership. Mr Robb says if a deal is reach then the benefits for Australian benefits will be huge. But consumer groups and other critics are worried that the Pacific trade pact could override national sovereignty and local laws.

title: Cocoa can help reverse age-related memory decline
abstract: US Scienists say high doses of cocoa flavanols can help reverse some of the effects of age-related memory decline. The doses required are far higher than would be found in normal foods, but it's possible a cocoa supplement might be developed as a result of the research to help improve memory.

abstract: Labor calls the reintroduction of fuel excise an ambush, but the Government defends the move, saying average families will pay only forty cents extra a week. The announcement that the Government is increasing excise without parliamentary approval has opened the way for Labor to chide the Government and to remind the public about other planned charges like the GP co-payment.

title: Motorists and lobbyists angry about another fuel tax hike
abstract: The reaction from motorists and lobby groups to the fuel tax increase has been scathing, with some describing it as a sneaky and gutless cash grab. While the Finance Minister describes the half a cent a litre increase as modest, it will still be too much for many people who are finding it hard to make ends meet.

The Commonwealth has announced it will give the ACT Government a $1 billion loan to demolish more than a thousand homes riddled with potentially deadly asbestos insulation. It's not the deal the Territory Government wanted, but for families that have been facing financial ruin and are still fearing for their health, it's a big relief.

Australia does scores highly for education, but the report says it's gone backwards on the number of women in political roles.

title: Adolf Eichmann's 'banality' entirely manufactured: Bettina Stangneth
abstract: The writer and philosopher Hannah Arendt, covering the trial of Nazi war criminal Adolf Eichmann for The New Yorker, coined the phrase 'the banality of evil' to describe Eichmann. She portrayed him essentially as the grey, faceless bureaucrat who organised the train timetables and all the other massively complex logistics necessary to murder 6 million Jews in cold blood. But now a new book says that's exactly what Eichmann wanted the world to think - and that he was in reality as much of a fanatical ideologue as Himmler or Geobbels. 'Eichmann Before Jerusalem: The Unexamined Life of a Mass Murderer' builds on documents from Eichmann's life in exile in Argentina.

title: Govt trying to confirm death of Australia's most senior jihadist
abstract: The Federal Government says it is working to confirm reports of the death of the most senior Australian recruiter for the so-called Islamic State. The ABC understands 33-year-old Mohammed Ali Baryalei from Sydney was killed in Syria in recent days. His role in recruiting scores of Australians to join Islamic State, and his alleged involvement in a plot for a terror attack on home soil has made him one of the most wanted Australians involved in the conflict.

title: Winners of PM's Prize for Science call for more support for scientific research

Sam Berkovic and Ingrid Scheffer have revolutionised the diagnosis and treatment of epilepsy. They were also able to debunk the myth that vaccination can cause the debilitating condition.

title: Tunisia votes in second election since ousting dictatorship
abstract: The Arab Spring began in Tunisia in 2010, and it's the one country where the result has been a peaceful transition to democracy rather than a civil war or a military crackdown. Tunisians have just voted for their government for the second time since ousting their dictatorship. Tunisian born Professor Fethi Mansouri of Deakin University was in the country during the campaign the recent parliamentary elections. He says poverty and unemployment - and a failure to combat Al Qaeda linked terrorism - were big factors in the loss by the Islamist party Ennahda.

title: Federal Government accused of strategic leaking on naval ship plans

title: Australia lacking leadership and consistency on Ebola
abstract: A leading HIV expert has drawn comparisons between that disease and the one threatening the lives of thousands of people in west Africa, Ebola. Professor Sharon Lewin has just returned from Washington and says Australia is lacking leadership and consistency regarding the perceived threats posed by Ebola.

title: Still no deal for release of kidnapped Nigerian school girls
abstract: It's now more than six months since the Islamist extremist group Boko Haram kidnapped hundreds of Nigerian schoolgirls. The mass kidnapping in the Chibok region shocked the world. The Nigerian government says it's negotiating with Boko Haram to see the release of the girls in exchange for 16 Boko Haram prisoners. But a human rights activist involved in those talks says a deal is still some time away.

title: Challenges ahead as US central bank unwinds quantitative easing
abstract: As the US central bank ends its six years of money printing, a former Federal Reserve chairman has predicted more turmoil ahead in financial markets. Alan Greenspan, the man blamed for creating the conditions which led to the global financial crisis, says there is no easy exit from the easy money policies. Analysts say the real crunch will come next year when the Fed raises official interest rates, especially in Asia.

title: Govt under pressure to explain how it can meet emissions target without paying polluters more than $2.5b
abstract: After striking a deal with Clive Palmer yesterday on climate change, the Federal Government has come under pressure to explain how it works. Labor's demanded the Government explain how it can meet its emissions reduction target at a cost of only $2.5 billion. It says the Government will have to either pay big polluters more to bring down emissions or it will fail to meet that goal.

title: Nova Peris says explicit email leak was part of a blackmail attempt
abstract: Federal Labor backbencher Nova Peris has delivered an extraordinary speech to the Senate, claiming explicit emails were used to try to blackmail her. The emails were published in newspapers this week. The Northern Territory Senator and Olympic Gold medallist today rejected suggestions she used taxpayers' money to bring Trinidadian track star Ato Boldon to Australia so the pair could pursue an affair. Senator Peris says the publication of the emails is part of a long-running family dispute and insists she's done nothing wrong.

title: Lawyers not obliged to be sympathetic and fairness is hard to define: Crown solicitor
abstract: Lawyers acting for the state of New South Wales have been accused of deliberately misleading a court during years of legal action involving abuse victims from the Bethcar children's home. In testimony before the royal commission a senior barrister who advised the state has defended the strategy of being deliberately selective about witnesses and documents and denied breaching any ethical obligations during the litigation. But the Crown solicitor has admitted to multiple breaches of the model litigant policy, but he says the policy doesn't demand lawyers be compassionate or sympathetic.

Tensions between Arabs and Jews have been revived over Israel's plans to build about 1,000 homes in the same area of the city the Palestinians are demanding for their state.

title: Victims call for royal commission into Defence abuse
abstract: Victim support groups have renewed their calls for a royal commission into abuse within the Defence Forces. They were reacting after the tabling of a long awaited parliamentary report into the way Defence supports abuse victims. The committee made nine recommendations, including the re-opening of the Defence Abuse Response Taskforce and the better resourcing of support services for victims. title: Apple CEO's gay statement seen as helpful for fostering tolerance
abstract: One day, perhaps, it won't be news when a well-known public figure comes out as gay. But not yet, to judge by the worldwide headlines about the chief executive of Apple, Tim Cook, doing just that. Mr Cook released an open letter discussing his homosexuality, saying he hoped it would help others. Gay and lesbian rights groups have welcomed his public comments, particularly in Apple's second biggest market China.

Her lectures have the broad title How To Hack Your Home.

title: Organ trafficking increase in Thailand
abstract: In Thailand, medical tourism is thriving but there's growing concern it's fuelling a rise in transplant tourism. The United Nations is warning the most vulnerable in the region are suffering as organ trafficking increases, with rich foreigners flocking to the Thai capital with money to spend. The UN says there's evidence to show Cambodian nationals are being paid as little $3,000 for a kidney.

title: Commemorations mark the beginning of Western Australia's Great War

title: Climate change report puts fresh pressure on Australian Government

The man in his twenties claims they were forced to sign papers withdrawing their witness accounts of what happened the night Iranian asylum seeker Reza Berati died in detention. He has spoken publicly for the first time about what he says Wilson Security guards and Transfield staff did to him in a secret compound called Chauka.

title: Australian bank profits hit record $29 billion

title: Asbestos remains persistent problem in Australia
abstract: For 40 years asbestos has been the story that just won't go away. It's not just that it can take 20 years or more to develop the worst asbestos diseases - it's that we keep assuming the problem's been dealt with. But Australia was one of the highest users per capita in the world up until the mid-1980s, and asbestos has been found on the site of one of the country's largest and busiest hospitals.

title: Climate Council warns of bushfire risk in SA, volunteers walk off the job
abstract: The Climate Council says the number of paid firefighters in Australia will have to double by 2030 to cope with an increased risk of blazes. It's just released a report on the bushfire threat in South Australia, warning that fires will last longer and be more frequent in the future. It comes as some volunteer firefighters in the state are refusing to fight fires on government land. They're incensed at a tax hike from the State Government to cover emergency services costs.

title: Investigators focus attention on SpaceShipTwo's tail section rather than engine
abstract: A US investigation into the crash of the Virgin Galactic spacecraft has found the ship broke up in mid-air, and it was unlikely the crash was due to an explosion in the engine or the fuel tank. The American National Transportation Safety Board has today focused attention on SpaceShipTwo's specially designed tail section.

title: Cambodia's democracy a facade: Sebastian Strangio
abstract: One of the few possible choices for people on Manus or Nauru, if they're accepted as refugees, might be to go and live in Cambodia. There are still few details of how many will go there under the arrangement Scott Morrison sealed with a champagne toast in Phnom Penh, or the conditions in which they'll live. But despite two decades of elections, Cambodia is still ruled by one man - Hun Sen - and it ranks 160th out of 177 countries on the Transparency International Corruption Index. Sebastian Strangio is a journalist whose new book is called Hun Sen's Cambodia. He says the country's government is not a democracy but a corrupt oligarchy.

title: AMWU claims workers fear the sack for admitting depression

The union says an online survey of more than 300 FIFO workers in the Pilbarra revealed widespread fears that admitting to mental ill-health would put their jobs at risk. But the Association of Mining and Exploration Companies (AMEC) says that's news to them, and mining companies have already put a range of mental health support services in place.

title: ABS revisions push up jobless rate to 6.2 per cent

The surprise jump in Australia's jobless rate came ahead of the next round of official employment numbers - due on Thursday. The reason: the Australian Bureau of Statistics was forced to revise up September's unemployment rate because of problems with its calculations. In a statement released today, the bureau says it has ironed out the statistical errors that damaged the credibility of its labour force survey in recent months.

title: Health study into Hazelwood smoke
abstract: The Victorian Government has announced a 20-year study into the health effects of February's coal mine fire in Hazelwood, in Victoria's east. It'll be led by Monash University, and will investigate the impacts of the fire's toxic fumes on nearby Morwell residents.
subject: Hazelwood;  open-cut mine;  fire;  Morwell;  carbon monoxide;  Monash University;  Judi Walker;  PM 2.5; respiratory conditions; Health -- Medical Research

title: Pop star Taylor Swift undermines world's biggest music streaming service
abstract: In a major blow to the world's largest music streaming service, one of the pop world's biggest stars has pulled all her music from it. Taylor Swift and her record label have yanked her catalogue from Spotify - a Swedish-based subscription service that's been credited with helping to stem music piracy. The reasons appear to be a mix of shrewd marketing and anger over the small royalties artists receive from the service. And she's just the latest in a growing line of famous musicans to undermine the streaming model of distribution.

title: ACDC drummer accused in murder plot
abstract: The drummer of the biggest selling Australian rock band AC/DC has appeared in court in New Zealand accused of trying to arrange two murders. Phil Rudd has been with the band since 1975, albeit with a break of several years in the middle, and there've been rumours in recent weeks about his future with AC/DC.

title: Questions asked about company awarded contract to run Ebola facility
abstract: Questions are being asked how the private company appointed to run Australia's response to the Ebola crisis in west Africa will train its staff. The Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade awarded the contract to Aspen Medical yesterday. Yet more questions are being asked as to why Australian Medical Assistance Teams or AUSMAT are not part of the Ebola response in Africa.

title: Families of murdered Bowraville children seek apology
abstract: The families of three children murdered more than 20 years ago on the mid north coast of NSW want an apology from the NSW Government over the handling of the case. The killer of two 16-year-olds, Colleen Walker Craig and Clinton Speedy Duroux, and 4-year-old Evelyn Greenup has never been caught.

title: Coal baron enters the Victorian election race
abstract: Clive Palmer has launched his election campaign for Victoria. He's fielding candidates in all eight Upper House electorates and thinks he can win the balance of power. He wants to end what he says is 'a morally repugnant' state of politics in Victoria.

title: Fairfax revenue falls, News Corp says its newspapers are rebounding
abstract: The fortunes of Australia's two biggest newspaper publishers appear to have diverged during the first few months of this financial year. Just months after returning to profit, Fairfax has told shareholders today that its advertising revenue is falling. But Rupert Murdoch's News Corporation says income from its Australian operations is rising.

title: Inside the dark heart of narco-terrorism

title: Bird numbers down in Australia's east as big dry takes its toll
abstract: A scientist leading an aerial survey of Australia's eastern waterbirds says there's been a significant decline in numbers since the boom brought about by the Queensland floods three years ago. And the longer term trend is even more stark. Researchers from the University of New South Wales have been conducting an annual aerial survey spanning wetlands from the far north Queensland coast across to the Northern Territory border. Over the past month, the team has been winding their way south, and they're now at the Lower Lakes area of South Australia. From there, scientist Richard Kingsford spoke to PM's Bill Birtles.

title: ICAC could set 'dangerous precedent' with NSW prosecutor
abstract: Lawyers for high profile NSW prosecutor Margaret Cunneen have warned if she is dragged before the ICAC next week it will create a 'very dangerous precedent' for all public officials. Ms Cunneen has launched a challenge in the NSW Supreme Court, calling for the ICAC to shut down an inquiry in which she has been accused of attempting to pervert the course of justice. Justice Clifton Hoeben is expected to hand down his decision late on Friday on whether the ICAC has exceeded its jurisdiction by going after the prosecutor.

title: Perth public hospitals no longer recruiting junior overseas-trained doctors
abstract: WA's Health Department chief says overseas-trained doctors are no longer needed to fill junior positions in Perth's public hospitals. Professor Bryant Stokes says increasing numbers of WA medical graduates mean locals can now fill those roles, but he says regional and remote communities will continue to rely on overseas doctors.

title: Charge dropped against AC/DC drummer, Phil Rudd
abstract: Prosecutors have withdrawn the most serious criminal charge against the AC/DC drummer Phil Rudd. Rudd was arrested in Tauranga, New Zealand, yesterday and accused of trying to hire a hitman to kill two people in September. That's the charge that's now been dropped.

title: Lambie anger with Government over defence pay extends to Palmer
abstract: Palmer United Party Senator Jacqui Lambie has lashed out at her leader while launching her campaign against the below inflation pay deal meted out to the defence forces. She's vowed to vote against all Government bills until the Coalition backs a bigger pay rise for the military, making it even tougher for the Government to negotiate its agenda through the Senate.

title: Freer flow of labour part of China-Australia trade talks
abstract: Australia and China are on the brink of a major trade deal with only two sticking points remaining. As APEC kicks off in Beijing, senior Government ministers are talking up the likelihood that an agreement will be ready to sign when president Xi Jinping visits Australia in a week's time.

title: 'Pick up artist' abandons tour, leaves after wide backlash
abstract: Women's rights activists are hailing it as a big victory. They targeted the self-styled American 'pick up artist' Julien Blanc with pickets and a social media campaign, and now he's the left the country. Blanc posts videos of himself choking women and forcing their faces into his crotch, among other things. His seminar tour was designed as an opportunity for others to learn his methods of manipulation and psychological games to attract women.

title: Community-led programs the key to reducing Indigenous suicide, experts say
abstract: Indigenous leaders say the death of an 11-year-old Aboriginal boy in Geraldton, Western Australia again highlights the need for grassroots suicide prevention programs. One Aboriginal leader in the Kimberley says one-size-fits-all programs to prevent suicide aren't working, and that instead, communities need to be empowered to help themselves.

title: Thirtieth anniversary of UN convention on torture
abstract: This week marks the 30th anniversary of the ratification of the United Nations Convention against Torture and Other Cruel, Inhuman or Degrading Treatment or Punishment. Representatives from Australia are appearing before the UN's Committee Against Torture today, including disability advocates. Damian Griffis, the chief executive officer of the First Peoples Disability Network Australia, is there and spoke with PM earlier.

title: Dollar hits four-year low, RBA says it needs to fall further
abstract: The Australian dollar has tumbled to another four-year low. But the Reserve Bank says it still has not fallen far enough. The RBA has released its quarterly update on monetary policy today. And it says the recent big decline in the value of the Australian dollar against the greenback has done little to support the domestic economy.

title: Silk Road 2.0 and other black markets taken offline by FBI
abstract: The Federal Bureau of Investigations has smashed a number of online black market bazaars for buying drugs, including the second version of the notorious Silk Road. The FBI has been investigating Silk Road 2.0 since it popped up in October 2013.

abstract: Republicans are warning Barack Obama he's 'playing with fire' if he plans to use executive orders to override Congress in the final two years of his presidency. With the GOP and president Obama at odds over a host of issues, from immigration to the budget, it's far from clear this week's election result will translate into any more cooperation on Capitol Hill.

title: Vic pollies asked to combat 'intimate terrorism'
abstract: Victoria's leading organisations against domestic violence want the issue put at the top of the state's election agenda. They say domestic violence should be considered intimate terrorism and responded to as such, with broad frameworks. Victoria's political parties will be asked to commit themselves to policies across housing, justice, police, health and education.

title: Wayne Goss remembered as courageous Queensland reformer
abstract: Queensland's former Labor premier Wayne Goss is being remembered today as a man of honesty and intergrity, who cleaned up the state during a turbulent time. In 1989, Mr Goss ended the National Party's 32-year reign in Queensland, marking the beginning of a new era.

Today China's premier Li Keqiang met with the United States president Barack Obama. Tony Abbott is also due to meet those two leaders, on the sidelines of a meeting which is ostensibly about trade and regional economic cooperation.

title: Fate of Islamic State leader unclear after airstrike
abstract: Mystery surrounds the fate of the man who appointed himself Caliph of the so-called Islamic State, Abu Bakr al-Baghdadi, after an American airstrike that targeted the leadership of the militant group. The US destroyed a convoy near the Iraqi city of Mosul, but officials say it's unclear whether al-Baghdadi was in any of the cars at the time. But experts believe stopping Islamic State won't be as simple as just getting rid of its leaders.

title: NSW prosecutor steps up legal challenge to ICAC in appeal court
abstract: New South Wales Crown Prosecutor Margaret Cuneen lost the first round of her legal challenge against the ICAC today to have the watchdog shut down an inquiry into claims she attempted to pervert the course of justice. But the ICAC has agreed to hold off on an inquiry pending an appeal hearing, set down for next week. Margaret Cuneen's high stakes battle with the ICAC has transfixed the Sydney legal fraternity since the prosecutor went public last week claiming she had been the target of a false and malicious complaint she had advised her son's girlfriend to fake chest pains after a car accident in May so she could avoid a blood alcohol test.

title: Marysville regenerates, along with its bushfire risk
abstract: Marysville is regenerating - emotionally and environmentally - after it was all but wiped out on Black Saturday. But with fuel loads also rebuilding, residents are anxious coming into this year's fire season. One retired bushfire scientist wants the state's fuel-reduction burning target increased. The Emergency Management Commissioner says the fire season could come early this year.

title: Germany celebrates 25th anniversary of the fall of the Berlin Wall
abstract: It was a chance to remember the joyous scenes of November 1989, when East and West Berliners fell into one another's arms and partied the night away. For nearly three decades East Germans had been - in the words of the current German president - not citizens of the state, but inmates of the state. The files of the East German secret police, the Stasi, became public property after the fall of the Wall, and a quarter of a century later the secrets they hold still make for uncomfortable reading.

title: Urgent effort needed to address seniors housing crisis
abstract: Researchers in Western Australia say urgent reform is needed to make sure older people are secure in their accomodation. A report has found many older people in private rentals in WA are afraid of being kicked out, or having their rent hiked, despite laws that are designed to stop that happening. The Council on Ageing WA says housing for seniors in the state is in 'crisis'.

title: Inquiry into convicted murderer and sex offender's escape to Chile
abstract: An inquiry is underway in New Zealand into how Phillip John Smith, a convicted murderer and child sex offender, fled to Chile after being allowed out of jail on a three-day visit. The fugitive prisoner caught a code-share LAN Chile-Qantas flight to Santiago on Thursday, but his disappearance wasn't discovered by authorities until more than 48 hours later.

title: Property investment still booming despite RBA warnings
abstract: The Reserve Bank's tough talk on house prices does not appear to be discouraging property investors. The value of loans handed out to landlords surged by almost 4 per cent in September, the same month the RBA raised the prospect of intervening in the market. But some economists expect investor demand to fade in the months ahead.

title: Unions say Government should pull out of negotiations on Trans-Pacific Partnership

The ACTU and the International Trade Union Confederation have written a joint letter to the Prime Minister Tony Abbott, asking him to stop the TPP talks. title: Close calls between Russian military and West on the rise
abstract: There's been a sharp increase in close military encounters between Russia and the West since Russia annexed Crimea eight months ago. A British think-tank has chronicled almost 40 episodes of dangerous brinkmanship. They include close encounters at sea and a narrowly avoided collision between a Scandanavian passenger jet and a Russian reconnaisance plane which did not transmit its position.

title: Ebola cases declining in Liberia, rising in Sierra Leone
abstract: No country has been worse hit by the Ebola outbreak than Liberia - it accounts for half of all the cases. But at least now there is some good news: the number of new cases there is declining for the first time since the beginning of the outbreak. But the situation in Liberia reversed in Sierra Leone, where the number of Ebola cases is continuing to rise - sharply.

title: Some Norfolk Islanders preparing for a fight over abolition of government
abstract: Norfolk Island has a brutal colonial past. Now, some residents in the small community 1,400 kilometres off the east coast of Australia claim they'll soon again be subject to 'colonial style' rule. The Commonwealth is considering scrapping the island's government early next year. It's in millions of dollars of debt, its roads are run down and the local residents don't pay Australian tax. Both sides of federal politics have had enough of bailing the island out.

title: Obama, Jinping agree on ambitious joint climate change strategy
abstract: The leaders of two of the world's biggest carbon emitters, president Barack Obama and president Xi Jinping, have announced new targets for carbon emissions reductions by the United States and a first-ever commitment by China to stop its emissions from growing by 2030. title: Palmer: Lambie won't follow through on threats

Clive Palmer says there's no chance his party will do a deal with the Government now the Opposition has walked away from negotiations. The mining magnate is still dealing with the fallout caused by one of his outspoken Senators. title: Asylum seekers given temporary refuee status in PNG
abstract: Ten asylum seekers currently detained on Manus Island will soon be given temporary refugee visas and a sense of freedom they haven't had in over a year. Papua New Guinea's immigration and foreign minister Rimbink Pato announced the first 10 positive refugee status determinations during a visit to Sydney to meet his Australian counterparts. The 10 men are from Pakistan, Iran, Afghanistan and Burma or Myanmar and they include an accountant, an engineer, a jeweller and a watchmaker.

title: Rosetta probe on track for history's first comet landing

The Australian OIC Cambodia Project aims to change that.

title: Palmer DisUnited Party: PUP leader and Lambie engage in slanging match

title: Secret police purge to be investigated by NSW Parliament
abstract: A festering row over a secret police corruption purge in New South Wales, which targeted more than 100 police, is about to be brought out into the open. The purge, conducted over five years from the late 1990s, resulted in a handful of convictions. But critics say most police targeted were the victims of false allegations. Yet 14 years on and three secret inquiries later, no-one has been made accountable. This week the New South Wales Upper House voted to establish a parliamentary select committee to publicly investigate what went wrong.

title: Liberal candidate muzzled after calling for abortion laws to be rolled back

The new seat of Buninyong is held by Labor by just 1.6 per cent and the Coalition is determined to win it back. The pro-choice Nationals candidate is now refusing to preference her Liberal counterpart. The Premier denies there's any tension between the Coalition partners.

title: The 'Toecutter' Reg Withers dies aged 90
abstract: Reg Withers, the Liberal senate leader charged with blocking Gough Whitlam's budget, has died. His family today revealed the man known as 'the Toecutter' died on Saturday, aged 90. Reg Withers has been remembered as a civic-minded man and a tough and cunning politician, who was a hero to his party through the Whitlam years.

title: Govt's financial advice rules face surprise defeat after Lambie, Muir abandon support
abstract: The Senate's decided to overturn the Government's controversial changes to financial advice laws, just four months after Clive Palmer struck a deal with the Coalition. PUP senator Jacqui Lambie and Ricky Muir have had a change of heart as divisions between Mr Palmer and Ms Lambie deepen.

title: Financial planners 'shocked' by FoFA change
abstract: Australia's financial planning association says it's shocked by the Senators' decision to swap camps on the FoFA measures. The group says its members have only had five months to adjust to the latest round of rule changes, and now they're worried they could end up unintentionally breaking the law.

title: 'He has broken more promises than most people have had hot dinners': Clare
abstract: Malcolm Turnbull's office yesterday led us to understand that he would be available for an interview today - then told us this afternoon that he wouldn't. In his absence I spoke to his Labor opposite number, Jason Clare. He says the announcement is a broken promise from Tony Abbott, and his excuses 'don't pass the pub test.'

title: Government confirms ABC and SBS cuts
abstract: After months of speculation about cuts to the budgets of the public broadcasters, the ABC and SBS, the Government has confirmed they will lose more than $300 million over the next five years. The Opposition says it's clearly in breach of a promise the Prime Minister made on the eve of the election.

title: Methane levels 'elevated' in air surrounding Queensland's Tara coal seam gas field
abstract: Scientific research published today casts new doubts on the environmental benefits of coal seam gas over conventional coal. Southern Cross University researchers found evidence of elevated levels of the dangerous greenhouse gas methane in air samples from around Queensland's Tara gas field. The tests showed levels three times above normal.

title: Elite Tasmanian school admits it should have apologised earlier to abuse sufferer
abstract: The Royal Commission into child sexual abuse is holding hearings in Tasmania for the first time. It is investigating allegations at the prestigious Hutchins School in Hobart, with four former students alleging sexual abuse by six teachers there in the 1960s. The commission heard how one survivor began his quest for justice 20 years ago, and it was only last month that the school apologised as the commission's hearings loomed.

title: Breaking the toilet taboo to improve global sanitation
abstract: Westerners don't typically consider toilets to be an appropiate topic for polite conversation, but Engineers Without Borders says that needs to change if the world is going to address the huge health and development issues facing people without access to proper sanitation. That's more than 2.5 billion people worldwide. They've used an unusual art installation at Sydney's Circular Quay to start the conversation on World Toilet Day.
subject: toilet;  sanitation;  engineers without borders;  development;  health; Health

title: Australia gets new facility to study decomposing bodies
abstract: For the first time, Australian forensic scientists are getting their own research facility to study decomposing human bodies. Until now, researchers have had to use data from America, where so-called 'body farms' have been used for decades. Forensics experts say they'll now be able to conduct vital research to assist police investigations.

title: World Parks Congress wraps with criticism of Australia

There's also been criticism of the host nation from at least one visiting minister for not moving further on climate change.

title: Smelly organic matter found on comet reveal beginnings of Planet Earth
abstract: Humanity's first ever probe of a comet has found evidence of smelly organic matter which could be the missing link to understanding how Planet Earth was created. The German Aerospace Centre today revealed its gas analysing instrument the COSAC had sniffed the comet's surface and detected organic molecules in the atmosphere. Astrophysicist Joss Bland Hawthorn, a Professor of Physics and director of the Sydney Institute for Astronomy, says scientists have long speculated astroids and comets colliding with the earth provided the critical molecules that transformed a primeval soup into earth, even life as we know it.

title: Fmr Judge says ICAC not a 'toothless tiger'
abstract: Already declared corrupt by the NSW ICAC, Obeid is to be prosecuted for the offence of misconduct in public office over his family's secretive business interest in lucrative leases at Sydney's Circular Quay. These are the first of what may well be a string of prosecutions flowing from high profile corruption inquiries conducted over the last two years. In each case, the charges against the three men could lead to jail sentences if they're found guilty.

title: CFMEU facing fines of up to $10 million for Boral secondary boycott
abstract: Australia's construction union the CFMEU is facing a legal battle that could cost it up to $10 million in fines. The competition watchdog is taking the union to court over its campaign to force the concrete giant Boral off building sites in Melbourne. The secondary boycott was allegedly part of a dispute between the CFMEU and the construction company Grocon that paralysed parts of the city two years ago.

title: WA Traditional Owners converge on Perth to protest Heritage Act changes
abstract: More than 60 Traditional Owners from around WA converged on Parliament House in Perth, to protest planned changes to the Aboriginal Heritage Act. They say they haven't been consulted, and the changes will make it easier for mining and development to destroy sacred sites. The WA Aboriginal Affairs Minister rejects that but says he'll take a close look at concerns around the right of appeal, raised with him at a meeting with Tradition Owners today.

title: Colonial delicasies 'Slippery Bob', 'Blow My Skull', wombat and turtle feature in 150 year old Australian cookbook
abstract: A 150 ago in the then colonies of Australia you might sit down to dinner and find wombat, mutton-bird or turtle on the menu. Your 1864 main course might have been something called 'Slippery Bob', washed down with a drink called 'Blow My Skull'. Both are mentioned in Australia's first cookbook, which is being republished after a century and a half. It's not for the gastronomically faint-hearted.

title: Qld Coroner calls for change to protect domestic violence victims
abstract: A coronial inquest into the brutal death of a young mother has revealed flaws in the way Queensland authorities deal with domestic violence. Noelene Beutel was killed by her partner in 2011. The coroner says doctors should be able to report domestic violence cases to police, with or without a patient's consent.

title: BHP sells demerger plan as AGM questions focus on environment

While the falling iron ore price was the elephant in the room, most questions from the floor concerned BHP's environmental record.Chairman, Jac Nasser, says BHP Billiton supports a carbon price but he wouldn't rule out more coal investments.

Labor and some crossbench senators say they're looking forward to the Senate returning to the way they think it should work - with more scrutiny of Government legislation.

He defended the lengths he'd gone to in his investigation and how seriously he treated the allegation.

title: Doctors concerned Australian women not getting access to services for severe post natal mental health problems
abstract: Post-natal depression can be a difficult and challenging experience for any new mum. About 600 Australian women each year experience the most extreme form of the condition - called postpartum psychosis. Despite the condition being long recognised among psychiatrists health authorities have been slow to respond. Many states in Australia do not have dedicated mental health beds for keeping mother and baby safe.

title: Regional Victorians concerned phone blackspots leave them at bushfire risk

title: Obama's Great Barrier Reef gloom rejected by Australian foreign minister

She says the world's biggest coral reef will be conserved for generations to come, and the Government does not believe that it is in danger. But Barack Obama, in a speech at the University of Queensland during the G20 leaders summit last weekend, said global warming threatened the incredible natural glory of the reef.

title: Asylum seekers land on Micronesian island of Yap

Those on board have told locals that they left Indonesia more than 10 days ago and were told they could get to Australia, the US and New Zealand.

title: Relocation of agricultural agencies to the bush could cost millions

Senate Estimates has heard that the cost of breaking one agency's lease could be as much as $2.6 million alone. Shadow agriculture minister Joel Fitzgibbon claims the plan lacks proper cost-benefit analysis and that the move is a political stunt.

title: Many radicalised IS fighters have little religious knowledge: expert
abstract: If you want to tackle Muslim extremists, you must first understand the difference between Islam and Islamism. title: Headmaster accused of concern over bad publicity rather than abuse victim's dignity
abstract: The royal commission into child sex abuse is examining abuse by at least six teachers at Hobart's prestigious Hutchins School in the 1960s. title: What does the free trade deal with China mean for us
abstract: Amid all the hoopla of the G20 last week, Australia signed a monumental trade agreement with China this week. abstract: The Aboriginal Disability Justice Campaign estimates about 130 Indigenous and non-Indigenous people are in jail in Australia despite not having been convicted of any offence. title: Tasmanian holiday reward for Indigenous teenagers from Pilbara finishing school

title: Republicans threaten revenge after presidential order spares millions of US 'illegals' from deportation
abstract: Millions of America's illegal immigrants are celebrating across the country following an executive order by president Obama which offers at least half of them a chance to register as legal residents. The order breaks a six year impasse in Congress over long awaited immigration reforms for what is widely agreed is a broken immigration system. But Republicans are furious at the move and have threatened to retaliate by shutting down the government.

title: WA Government, Fortescue sign agreement to train, employ Aboriginal prisoners

The WA Corrections commissioner says he hopes the program can eventually be extended state-wide.

title: ABC supporters condemn cuts, 400 staff to go
abstract: Supporters of the national broadcaster have condemned the program and staff cuts announced today and laid the blame at the feet of the Federal Government. The ABC managing director Mark Scott has announced that Adelaide's TV production unit will close and state editions of 7.30 will be replaced by one national version. Mr Scott says across the corporation, more than 400 positions will go.

title: 'This is the sad fate of media organisations across Australia': Mark Scott
abstract: There is now a series of major differences between the Communications Minister Malcolm Turnbbull and the ABC managing director Mark Scott. They're not just differences of opinion, but differences of fact. I put it to Mark Scott first that there was a yawning gulf between Mr Turnbull's statements about a 5 per cent cut, and his own that the cuts amounted to 8 per cent. Mark Scott tells Mark Colvin, 'its a terribly sad day', and says to the people whose jobs will be cut, 'we share their abject pain and disappointment.'

title: Lambie's resignation leaves Govt with new equation to get enough support for bills
abstract: Tasmanian Senator Jacqui Lambie's decision to quit the Palmer United Party means Government strategists have a new set of calculations to make as they try to get bills through. Now that Senator Lambie has walked away from the Palmer Party, there are more possible combinations of Senators that can give the Government the six votes it needs. Senators from the major parties and other crossbenchers are being careful not to alienate the newly independent Senator. But Clive Palmer is furious with Senator Lambie, and is making no attempt to win her back to his party.

title: BHP Billiton says more job cuts likely as it looks to reduce costs

title: Senate committee to investigate ABC funding cuts
abstract: The ABC's cuts have again dominated Question Time in Federal Parliament. The Opposition has used the issue to attack the Prime Minister's trustworthiness, but Tony Abbott has taken that as a chance to deride Bill Shorten as fraud and a hypocrite.

title: Update on Australian Defence Force role in combatting Islamic State
abstract: The advance of the Sunni so-called Islamic State across Iraq has slowed, but the militants have stepped up suicide attacks and the use of improvised explosive devices. RAAF super hornets have dropped 20 bombs as part of a joint mission to retake control of a key oil facility north of Baghdad.

title: Phil Hughes critical
abstract: The Australian cricketer Phil Hughes is in a critical condition in hospital after a fast, sharply rising ball hit him during a Sheffield Shield match. The ground fell silent as Hughes collapsed to the ground unconscious and stopped breathing.

title: Clive James on his new poetry book and his distinctive voice
abstract: Clive James - as a recent ABC TV series underlined - is one of the greatest living creative Australians, but for how long? A humorist, broadcaster, TV Critic, literary critic, and self-described unreliable memoirist, Clive James would like above all to be remembered as a poet, and he has a new book out about poetry. Despite his ill-health, he granted PM a long interview from his home in Cambridge about Poetry Notebook 2006-2014.

title: Abuse survivor cynical at timing of Hutchins' apology
abstract: The child abuse Royal Commission has spent the best part of a week of hearings examining an abuse survivor's 20 year struggle to get an apology from the school he was abused at. The apology finally came last month, and today the commission has heard evidence that its hearings were the catalyst for it. The survivor's lawyer indicated her client is cynical about the sincerity of the apology.

title: More boys failing to complete HPV vaccine course
abstract: New Victorian statistics show boys are less likely to start and finish their course of the human papilloma virus vaccine than girls. Public health experts say it appears many parents don't appreciate that the vaccine is as important for boys as it is for girls.

title: Volunteers and parents demand answers over use of disability fundraising proceeds

Special Olympics Australia is in dire financial trouble, after a poorly managed Asia Pacific Games event held last year.

title: Aboriginal interpreting service welcomes Senate support, still pushing for funding
abstract: Western Australia's only Aboriginal interpreting service has welcomed the Federal Senate's support for its work. But says what it really needs is secure funding to make sure justice is served for Indigenous people in WA. State funding for the Kimberley Interpreting Service expired at the end of June, and it's not yet clear whether federal funding will continue beyond next year.

title: Medibank shares end first day of trade level at offer price
abstract: Medibank Private has had a bumpy debut on the the share market. The health insurer's shares surged to above 12 per cent above their retail offer price during the first few minutes of trade. But they closed at $2.14, just below the price institutional investors paid for them. Now shareholders are putting pressure on Medicare's management to start delivering profits to match its market value.

title: Ferguson police respond to continuing violence with show of force
abstract: It's well after midnight in Ferguson Missouri, and no-one's expecting that the next few hours will be peaceful, however many pleas for non-violence there've been. Last night saw widespread looting and burning after the announcement that the white police officer who shot a young black man, Michael Brown in August, would not even be charged. The London Guardian's reporter Paul Lewis has been on the streets of Ferguson and says police have used tear gas and confronted the people with their guns drawn.

title: Protests inspired by Ferguson unrest spread across US cities

title: Former ADFA cadet says Taskforce advice the right call
abstract: There has been astonishment that the Taskforce recommended a royal commission, given only three months ago, the Taskforce chairman Len Roberts-Smith had questioned whether a royal commission was necessary or appropriate. One of those pleasantly taken aback by the surprise outcome is Naomi Brooks. She joined ADFA as a cadet in 2009, but dropped out after she was actively persecuted by other cadets after complaining to her superiors about the bullying and intimidation.

title: Government to consider royal commission into defence abuse
abstract: The Federal Government says it will consider whether to act on the call from the Defence Abuse taskforce and hold a royal commission into abuse at the Defence Force Academy - ADFA. The Taskforce says a royal commission is the only way to to ensure a thorough investigation of abuse issues at the Academy. It has tabled a report today with more shocking examples of abuse - including rape, bashings and bullying.

title: Senate censures Defence Minister
abstract: The Senate has voted to censure the Defence Minister David Johnston over his remarks yesterday that he wouldn't trust the Australian Submarine Corporation to build a canoe. Senator Johnston concedes he said the wrong thing, but has brushed it off as a rhetorical flourish. The Greens and several other cross benchers supported Labor's censure motion, which doesn't hold any legal weight.

title: WA Opposition demands independent review of policy that jails fine defaulters

Labor's corrective services spokesman Paul Papalia says the policy doesn't work, costs the state millions, and disproportionately hurts the most disadvantaged members of West Australian society. The policy is again in the spotlight after the August death in custody of Miss Dhu, a 22-year-old Aboriginal woman who'd been jailed over unpaid fines.

title: Small investors say Medibank float 'unfair'
abstract: Investors are questioning the fairness of the Medibank Private float. The Australian Shareholders Association says potentially thousands of investors were blocked from cashing in on a big spike in the company's share price in the hours after it listed. They say they've been excluded from first few days of trade, and their chance to turn a quick profit is fading fast. Medibank's share price has made a hard landing on the insurer's second day of trade.

title: Biological family of girl who committed suicide in foster care demand answers
abstract: Fourteen-year-old Karmah Jayne Hall took her own life in September at her foster parents' north-western Sydney property. Her biological mother and siblings say they first learned of her death on Facebook and that authorities have kept them in the dark ever since, and they're alarmed that her foster father has been investigated over abuse allegations made by another foster child in his care.

title: Oxycodone to blame for more than 800 deaths
abstract: It's one of the most popular and effective prescription painkillers, but new research shows Oxycodone has contributed to the deaths of more than 800 Australians in recent years. It's a seven-fold increase in deaths related to the drug between 2001 and 2011. The study calls on doctors to exercise more caution when prescribing the drug.

title: Consumer lease companies accused of targeting vulnerable people
abstract: Consumer groups and community leaders say people in remote parts of Queensland are being locked into contracts to lease household items such as fridges and washing machines at massively inflated prices. title: Speaker Bronwyn Bishop ejects a record number of MPs from Question Time
abstract:
The House of Representatives Speaker, Bronwyn Bishop, has set a record today ejecting 18 MPs, all Labor, from Question Time. Forty-seven MPs have now been told to leave for an hour this week and 285 since she became Speaker - all but five are Labor. Ms Bishop told Parliament it is pathetic for the Opposition to argue they were behaving like angels and she was picking on them.
And senior Government frontbencher, Christopher Pyne, said Labor ran a deliberate strategy of attempting to be thrown out.

title: PM urged to try harder on engaging with Indigenous Australians
abstract: The Social Justice commissioner Mick Gooda has tabled his 2014 report calling on the Prime Minister and his Government to try harder to engage with Indigenous communities. Both have called on the Government to introduce specific justice targets in efforts to close the gap of Indigenous disadvantage.

The damage bill has already hit 60 million dollars, but it's expected to increase.

title: Ex-Australian soldier says Iraq's army ill equipped to combat Islamic State
abstract: It was June when the so-called Islamic State stormed through Northern Iraq, but nearly six months later, there's little sign that the Iraqi army's in much of a position to push them out. Reuters newsagency, in fact, reports a top Kurdish official as saying they won't be ready to do so till late next year. Many believe Mosul should never have been allowed to fall in the first place, and that it only happened because of a catastrophic collapse by the Iraqi army. Now an ex-Australian soldier who trained Iraqi recruits has broken ranks to give an insider's account of why that may have happened.

title: Consumers tell Qantas to dump fuel surcharge after oil price crash

title: Health company investigated for prioritising profits ahead of patients

Experts say such offers encourage doctors to bill extra unncessary tests and appointments, known as over-servicing. Over-servicing is against the law and costs Medicare money.

title: Amnesty says Government breaching refugee convention in Darwin stand-off
abstract: Amnesty says the Government is breaching the refugee convention by trying to detain two refugee women who are eight months pregnant and have been brought to Australia from Nauru to give birth. The familes are sitting in a bus outside a detention centre in Darwin and are refusing to go inside as they want to stay in the community while they wait to give birth. The Immigration Minister's office says, 'The Minister has been advised these individuals were not informed they would be placed in the community.'

title: Former health minister Michael Wooldridge banned for breach of Corporations Act

The reason is his role in the collapse of the $500 million Prime property trust. The retirement village group's founder and chief executive Bill Lewski paid himself $33 million after directors changed the Prime's constitution. He's been banned for 15 years and fined $230,000.

title: Navy veterans talks of stress during border protection operations

title: ABARES dramatically revises down grain harvest estimates, worrying farmers

title: Australian dollar plunges after economic growth slows
abstract: A sharp slowdown in economic growth has pulled Australia into what's being called an income recession. Official figures released today show gross domestic product increased by 0.3 per cent in the September quarter. It's half the rate economists were expecting. The annual growth rate has slumped to 2.7 per cent, triggering a drop in the value of the dollar to a new four-year low.

title: Cheaper HPV vaccines could help prevent cervical cancer in poorer countries
abstract: Every year, almost 300,000 women die from cervical cancer which can be prevented by a vaccine. Almost all of the deaths are in poor countries where less than 10 per cent of women get access to the Human Papilloma Virus - or HPV - vaccine. The retail cost of the vaccine is $130, but a group dedicated to providing low cost vaccines says it has a solution to the problem by making the vaccine available for less than $5.

title: Documents reveal details behind fatal delay to transferring ill asylum seeker off Manus
abstract: Documents obtained by the ABC reveal that no-one acted for more than 24 hours on a request to move a seriously ill asylum seeker from Manus Island for urgent treatment - and that medical staff at the detention centre did not have the antibiotics needed to save his life. The woman known to the inquiry as Shishy has denied allegations that she knowingly procured girls for the guru, and said that she too was a victim of violent physical and humiliating sexual abuse.

title: Australia's women physicists say they're losing the fight for gender equity

title: China has made no commitment to abandon a one party state: analyst
abstract: Trade Minister Andrew Robb has insisted that China's president Xi Jinping had said his objective by 2050 was to have a democratic community, but China experts in the rest of the world have unanimously interpreted that as meaning something very different from any Western definition of democracy. PM speaks to Nicholas Bequelin, a senior researcher in the Asia division of Human Rights Watch, who says the Government's statements may be a deliberate attempt to mislead the Australian public into a false sense of security about the country to which Australia has tied itself more closely with the Free Trade Agreement.

The blue Santos logo is displayed on some Queensland Police cars as part of an outback road safety campaign. The Lock the Gate Alliance argues it's an unacceptable conflict of interest, but police are standing firm.

title: University overhaul: Abbott Government begins ad blitz

In moves unlikely to surprise many, the Government has appointed a new head of Treasury, the Prime Minister's backing down further on his Paid Parental Leave scheme and taxpayers' money is being spent advertising the Coalition's contentious university overhaul. It's all fresh fodder for a Labor Opposition, buoyed by another strong poll and another state ALP election result.

title: Industry welcomes help on defence shipbuilding
abstract: The Federal Government says it's drawing a line in the sand when it comes to the future of naval shipbuilding in the country. An expert team is being brought in to help get the troubled Air Warfare Destroyer project in Adelaide back on track. The Government says how successful that is will help determine whether Australia can support the industry going forward - including the next submarine build. The defence industry body in South Australia has welcomed the news, saying it's the first positive step forward in months.

title: Government drops $7 GP co-payment policy

Tony Abbott has signalled the end of the co-payment on visits to the GP announced in the Budget. But where the public may no longer have to fork out the price of two flat whites, the Government will take $5 off the Medicare rebate paid to doctors for some consultations. Pensioners, children, veterans and people in nursing homes would be exempt.

title: Government caves on hardline anti-piracy laws
abstract: The Abbott Government appears to have abandoned its push for tough anti-piracy laws, plumping instead for a much softer online copyright regime. Uploading pirates will be sent warning notices but there will be no punishments for consumers. Plans to compel internet providers services to help track down offenders have also been dumped. The Government is expected to announce the new laws later this week.

title: ABS says employment data can be trusted after independent review

The ABS has accepted all the recommendations from an independent report into statistical problems that caused it to recalculate a year's worth of employment data. The report found that changes to supplementary surveys of jobseekers caused the problems. The Bureau has sinced changed the way it does its Labour Force survey.
