title: Tollner set to return to Cabinet after exile over alleged gay slur
abstract: The former Northern Territory treasurer Dave Tollner, who resigned earlier this year over an alleged gay slur, is set to make a return to the Cabinet. The Territory's Chief Minister Adam Giles today described Mr Tollner as a very wise man with a lot to contribute, and it's expected that later this week he'll announce Mr Tollner's return to the front bench. Mr Tollner previously described his parliamentary colleagues as a nest of vipers and suggestions about his return have already raised eyebrows among some of his colleagues.

title: Lima climate meeting to pave the way for Paris

It allows users to engage in activities that many of us take for granted, such as hand shaking, holding a ball, or knowing if a cup of liquid is hot or cold. And one of Australia's leading burns surgeons is hopeful the new 'smart skin' might also be of use in treating burnt flesh.

However, the asylum seekers have told supporters they will only be provided with six weeks accommodation. In the midst of the holiday season, there is concern they may struggle to find other housing, so a group of locals is rallying to try to find options for them.

title: Government challenges opposing sides of piracy war to find joint solution

title: Police 'culture of toughness' directly linked to rise in suicide and corruption
abstract: The country's leading researcher on the psychological injuries among police says a nationwide push to put more police on the front line over the past three decades has come at a catastrophic cost to their health. University of Adelaide professor, Sandy McFarlane, says more than one police in three now suffers from serious psychological injuries from their work but get little help from police managers due to a culture of toughness. Governments across the country have also failed police, he said, with the rate of suicides a national scandal.

The rate of under utilisation, that's the number of people who have less work than they want, rose to 15 per cent.

title: Loopholes exploited in Sydney's Opal ticketing system

title: Lone gunman brings Sydney CBD to a standstill, motivation still unclear
abstract: As recently as September when police raided hundreds of people around Australia as an anti-terrorism measure, there were warnings of a planned attack on members of the general public. At 9.45 in Sydney this morning, a lone armed gunman took an unknown number of people hostage at Martin Place's Lindt cafe. Soon after television broadcast pictures of frightened hostages at the cafe's window holding a black flag with arabic writing on it. Martin Place was blockaded, many buildings were locked down and streets closed off. Since then, three hostages have got away, but It's unclear how many hostages remain.

title: 'He will be identified today'

He says no sure links can be made until there is a declaration of intent from the gunman. At the same time, there are questions over what other threats the siege gunman may wield that are keeping the hostages from over-powering him.

title: Hockey: Budget deficits blow out with $3.7b more cut from foreign aid

The Opposition says the Government's just put the surplus 'off to the never never' and broken another election promise.

title: PUP media adviser in court over kidnapping charges
abstract: Clive Palmer's media adviser and confidant, Andrew Crook, has appeared in court facing allegations he was involved in the kidnapping of a National Australia Bank executive.

title: Martin Place tributes flow for victims of deadly siege
abstract: The makeshift floral tribute for the victims of Monday's deadly siege in Sydney is cascading hundreds of metres down Martin Place. The families of the victims killed by gunman, Man Haron Monis, say they've been overwhelmed by the response. Many mourners would like a permanent memorial to be established at Martin Place.

title: National Gallery to investigate whether 54 works in collection were looted
abstract: The National Gallery is facing more questions about how dozens of treasured artefacts found their way into Australia's art collection. It is hiring an independent auditor to trace the ownership histories of 54 south Asian works to make sure they have not been looted. In September, it was forced to return the 900-year-old Dancing Shiva statue to India after it was found to have been stolen from a temple.
subject: national gallery of australia;  art;  museums;  gerad vaughn; crime; Arts and Entertainment -- Library Museum and Gallery

title: UN wants 'big surge' in effort to reduce Ebola transmission rate
abstract: The World Health Organization says almost 7,000 people have been killed by the Ebola virus in west Africa. Now the United Nations is calling for a big surge in efforts to reduce transmission rates in western parts of Sierra Leone. Health officials are trying to ensure that hospitals in each capital city are ready for a potential outbreak.

title: Russian rouble crisis threatens global economy: Satyajit Das
abstract: Author and ex-banker Satyajit Das warns that the Russian rouble crisis could derail Europe's fragile economy, and its effects may even spread to Australia. The respected risk analyst also warns that the global commodity crunch will continue to send shockwaves through emerging economies and threaten financial stability.

title: New jeans protect credit cards from hacking
abstract: A San Francisco based clothing manufacturer has developed what are probably the world's first high security jeans. The jeans' pockets are lined with a metal fabric to stop thieves from hacking into credit cards and passports tagged with radio frequency security chips.
subject: fashion;  cybersecurity;  identity theft;  Chris Lindland; katina michael; Human Interest -- Offbeat

title: Barramundi: calls to restrict the name to Australian fish
abstract: The French have laid claim to the name 'champagne'. Now there's a push back. Independent Senator Nick Xenophon wants to reserve the name 'barramundi' for fish caught or farmed in Australia. Senator Xenophon will be introducing legislation next year requiring restaurants and take-away shops to label seafood as local or imported. He says preserving the barramundi name could boost the local industry.

title: Documentary Special: Quentin Bryce looks into the failure of domestic violence policies
abstract: Only a few months ago Dame Quentin Bryce was Australia's governor-general. During her long and varied career she has juggled great responsibility, often with a focus on the rights of women and children. Now she's tackling what she calls one of the worst human rights abuses: the rising threat of domestic violence. Ms Bryce has taken on the task of finding out why decades of policy and intervention haven't stopped the deadly trend.

title: Roaring twenties in Australia: finding our post-war identity
abstract: Over the next four years, Australia will be marking centenary moments from the so-called war to end all wars. More than 16 million people died in the war worldwide, 10 million of them soldiers, sailors, airmen and nurses. The 1920s began for Australia and for the rest of the world with as much grief and loss as a relief that victory was won and the illusion that peace was here to stay. The writer Tom Keneally's new book is called 'Australians: Flappers to Vietnam'. He says returned soldiers were supposed to come home to a land fit for heroes, but many were disappointed, and for the women who now greatly outnumbered men, there were terrible shocks and setbacks too.
subject: The Great War;  Tom Keneally;  World War One; Community and Society -- History -- World War 1

title: Clive James on history's great poets and mortality
abstract: Humorist, essayist, broadcaster, novelist and poet, Clive James is dying of leukaemia and emphysema. However, he's still writing and still hoping, with a new volume of poetry, Poetry Notebook: 2006-2014. Clive James spoke to Mark Colvin about his beginnings as a literature enthusiast, his thoughts on some of history's great writers and mortality.

title: Peter Carey: reflecting on the past and exploring the future
abstract: Peter Carey joins Mark Colvin to discuss the themes of his new work, Amnesia. The book ranges widely and often angrily over questions about Australia's relationship with the United States, Australian identity and personal freedom. In research for the new book, Carey examined the past, confronted the present, and explored the possibilities of the future.

title: A boarding school making an impact on Indigenous students
abstract: In the remote APY Lands in South Australia's outback, there are a number of obstacles for children getting an education. Truancy officers in the region are having a mixed impact - in some schools attendance rates have actually fallen. However, one program having an effect is the Wiltja School, an innovative boarding school in Adelaide which keeps a connection to country while giving students a secondary education.

title: Former head of NewsCorp Australia describes life in the Murdoch fiefdom
abstract: The former head of NewsCorp Australia, Kim Williams, discusses his memoir with Eleanor Hall. In this candid discussion, Mr Williams talks about running a company under the eye of Rupert Murdoch and speaks frankly about the ill-feeling towards him that still exists at News.
